Tellurium Methods¶

Utility Methods¶

The most useful methods here are the notices routines. Roadrunner will offen issue warning or informational messages. For repeated simulation such messages will clutter up the outputs. noticesOff and noticesOn can be used to turn on an off the messages.

Print Version information

import tellurium as te
te.getVersionInfo()

Repeat simulation without notification

# Load SBML file
r = roadrunner.RoadRunner('mymodel.xml')
# Turn of notices so they don't clutter the output
roadrunner.noticesOff()
for i in range (0:20):
  result = r.simulate (0, 10)
  r.plot (result)
  r.model.k1 = r.model.k1 + 0.2
# Turn the notices back on
roadrunner.noticesOn()

File helpers for reading and writing

r = te.loada('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 10')
saveToFile('mymodel.m', r.getMatlab())

sbmlstr = readFromFile('mymodel.xml')
tellurium.getVersionInfo()[source]¶

Prints version information for tellurium supported packages.

Returns:None
tellurium.getTelluriumVersion()[source]¶

Version number of tellurium.

Returns:version string
tellurium.noticesOff()[source]¶

Switch off the generation of notices to the user. Call this to stop roadrunner from printing warning message to the console. see also noticesOn()

tellurium.noticesOn()[source]¶

Switch on notice generation to the user. see also noticesOff()

tellurium.saveToFile(fileName, str)[source]¶

Save string to file.

saveToFile ('c:\myfile.txt', strVariable)
Parameters:
  • fileName – file path to save to
  • str – string to save
Returns:

None
tellurium.readFromFile(fileName)[source]¶

Load a file and return contents as a string.

str = readFromFile('c:\myfile.txt')
Parameters:fileName – file path to read from
Returns:string representation of the contents of the file

Model Loading¶

There are a variety of methods to load models into libRoadrunner. At the most basic level one can load the model directly using libRoadRunner:

r = roadrunner.RoadRunner('mymodel.xml')

Alternatively one can use these methods:

This is the same as roadrunner.RoadRunner() but the method name is more suggestive of what it does. Like RoadRunner, loadSBML can accept a file name or a SBML string as it argument

r = te.loadSBMLModel ('mymodel.xml')

# To load an Antimony model use:
r = te.loadAntimonyModel (antStr)

# Or alternatively
r = te.loadAntimonyModel ('mymodel.ant')

# The method loada is simply a shortcut to loadAntimonyModel
r = loada ('''
        S1 -> S2; k1*S1;
        S2 -> S3; k2*S2;

        k1= 0.1; k2 = 0.2;
        S1 = 10; S2 = 0; S3 = 0;
        ''')
        result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)
        r.plot (result)
tellurium.loadSBMLModel(sbml)[source]¶

Load an SBML model into roadRunner.

r = loadSBMLModel('c:\myfile.txt')
Parameters:sbml – SBML filename, SBML string or SBML uri
Returns:reference to roadrunner model

r = loadAntModel(antimonyStr)
Parameters:antStr – antimony string
Returns:reference to roadrunner model
tellurium.loada(antStr)[source]¶

Load model from antimony string. see also: :func:loadAntimonyModel

r = loada('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S2 = 10')
Parameters:antStr – antimony string
Returns:reference to roadrunner model
tellurium.loadCellMLModel(cellML)[source]¶

Load a cellml model into roadrunner.

r = loadCellMLModel ('mymodel.cellml')
Parameters:cellML – model to load, can be file or string
Returns:reference to roadrunner model

Interconversion Utilities¶

Use these routines interconvert verious standard formats

Convert an SBML model into Antimony

# Load an SBML file
sbmlStr = te.readFromFile('mymodel.xml')
# Generate the Antimony format of the SBML model
print(te.sbmlToAntimony(sbmlStr))

Convert an Antimony model into SBML

# Load an Antimony file
antStr = te.readFromFile('mymodel.ant')
# Generate the SBML format of the Antimony model
print te.antimonyToSBML(antStr)
tellurium.antimonyTosbml(antStr)[source]¶

Convert antimony string to SBML string.

sbmlStr = antimonyTosbml(antimonyStr)
Parameters:antStr – antimony string of model
Returns:SBML model as string
tellurium.sbmlToAntimony(str)[source]¶

Convert SBML string to antimony string.

sbmlStr = sbmlToAntimony(antimonyStr)
Parameters:str – SBML model as string
Returns:antimony string of model
tellurium.cellmlFileToAntimony(CellMLFileName)[source]¶

Convert cellml file to antimony string.

ant = cellMLToAntimony('mymodel.cellml')
Parameters:CellMLFileName – CellML file
Returns:antimony string of model

Convert cellml file to SBML string.

sbmlStr = cellMLToSBML('mymodel.cellml')
Parameters:CellMLFileName – CellML file
Returns:SBML string of model

Parameters:CellMLStr – CellML string
Returns:antimony string of model

Stochastic Simulation¶

Use these routines to carry out Gillespie style stochastic simulations.

Stochastic simulation:

r = te.loada('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 40')
r.setSeed(87675)
result = r.gillespie (0, 100)
r.plot(result)

Run two simulations and combine the two:

import numpy as np
import tellurium as te

r = te.loadSBMLModel ('mymodel.xml')
seed= r.getSeed()
result1 = r.gillespie (0, 100)
r.model.k1 = r.model.k1*20
result2 = r.gillespie (100, 200)
# Merge the two runs together
rr.plot(np.vstack ((result1, result))
tellurium.getSeed(r)[source]¶

Current seed used by the random generator of the RoadRunner instance.

myseed = rr.getSeed()
Parameters:r – RoadRunner instance.
Returns:current seed
tellurium.setSeed(r, seed)[source]¶

Set seed for random number generator (used by gillespie for example).

rr.setSeed(12345)
Parameters:
  • r – RoadRunner instance.
  • seed – seed to set
tellurium.gillespie(r, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Run a Gillespie stochastic simulation.

rr = te.loada ('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 40')

# Simulate from time zero to 40 time units
result = rr.gillespie (0, 40)

# Simulate on a grid with 10 points from start 0 to end time 40
result = rr.gillespie (0, 40, 10)

# Simulate from time zero to 40 time units using the given selection list
# This means that the first column will be time and the second column species S1
result = rr.gillespie (0, 40, ['time', 'S1'])

# Simulate from time zero to 40 time units, on a grid with 20 points
# using the give selection list
result = rr.gillespie (0, 40, 20, ['time', 'S1'])
Parameters:
  • r – RoadRunner instance
  • args – parameters for simulate
  • kwargs – parameters for simulate
Returns:

simulation results

SEDML¶

Math¶

Only one routine is currently available in this group which is a routine to compute the eigenvalues of given a matrix.

import numpy as np
import tellurium as te

m = np.matrix([[1,2],[5,7]])
print(te.getEigenvalues(m))
tellurium.getEigenvalues(m)[source]¶

Eigenvalues of matrix. Convenience method for computing the eigenvalues of a matrix m Uses numpy eig to compute the eigenvalues.

Parameters:m – numpy array
Returns:numpy array containing the eigenvalues

Plotting¶

Two useful plotting routines. They assume that the first column in the array is the x-axis and the second and subsequent columns represent curves on the y-axis.

# Load a model and carry out a simulation generating 100 points
r = te.loada ('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 10')
result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)

# No legend will be add to the plot, useful for plotting large
# numbers of curves where a legend would get in the way
te.plotArray (result)

# To get a legend use the roadrunner plot command
r.plot (result)
tellurium.plotWithLegend(r, result=None, loc='upper left', show=True)[source]¶

Plot an array and include a legend. The first argument must be a roadrunner variable. The second argument must be an array containing data to plot. The first column of the array will be the x-axis and remaining columns the y-axis. Returns a handle to the plotting object.

plotWithLegend (r)
Parameters:
  • r – RoadRunner instance
  • result – results to plot
  • loc – location of plot legend
  • show – show the plot
Returns:

plt object
tellurium.simulateAndPlot(r, startTime=0, endTime=5, numberOfPoints=500, **kwargs)[source]¶

Run simulation and plot the results.

simulateAndPlot (rr)
simulateAndPlot (rr, 0, 10, 100)
Parameters:
  • r – RoadRunner instance
  • startTime – start time of simulation
  • endTime – end time of simulation
  • numberOfPoints – number of points in simulation
Returns:

simulation results
tellurium.plotArray(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot an array. The first column of the array will be the x-axis and remaining columns the y-axis. Returns a handle to the plotting object. Note that you can add plotting options as named key values after the array. For example to add a legend, include the label key value: te.plotArray (m, label=’A label’) then use pylab.legend() to make sure the legend is shown.

result = numpy.array([[1,2,3], [7.2,6.5,8.8], [9.8, 6.5, 4.3]])
plotArray(result)
tellurium.plot(self, result=None, loc='upper left', show=True)[source]¶

Plot data generated by a simulation. Plot results from a simulation carried out by the simulate or gillespie functions. This is a roadrunner method. Data is a numpy array where the first column is considered the x axis and all remaining columns the y axis. If no data is provided the data currently held by roadrunner generated in the last simulation is used.

r.plot()
Parameters:
  • self – RoadRunner instance
  • result – results data to plot
  • loc – location of plot legend
  • show – show the plot
Returns:

?

Model Reset¶

Use these routines reset your model back to particular states

r = te.loada ('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 10')
result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)
p.model.S1 = 2.0
result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)
# Reset the model back to its original state
r.reset()

If you wish to reset a model back to the state it was what it was loaded, use the resetToOrigin method

r = te.loada ('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 10')
result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)
# Make lots of different kinds of changes to the model
# Reset the model back to the state it had when it was created
r.resetToOrigin()
tellurium.resetToOrigin(self)[source]¶

Reset model to state when first loaded. This resets the model back to the state when it was FIRST loaded, this includes all init() and parameters such as k1 etc.

te.resetToOrigin()
identical to:
te.reset(roadrunner.SelectionRecord.ALL)
tellurium.resetAll(self)[source]¶

Reset all model variables to CURRENT init(X) values. This resets all variables, S1, S2 etc to the CURRENT init(X) values. It also resets all parameters back to the values they had when the model was first loaded.

rr.resetAll()

Export¶

Matlab export utilities

Use these routines to convert your model into a Matlab function.

r = te.loada('S1 -> S2; k1*S1; k1 = 0.1; S1 = 10')
print(r.getMatlab())
r.exportToMatlab("mymodel.m")
tellurium.getMatlab(self)[source]¶

Matlab string of current model.

Returns:Matlab string
tellurium.exportToMatlab(self, fileName)[source]¶

Save current model as Matlab file.

rr.exportToMatlab ('mymodel.m')
Parameters:fileName – file path of matlab file
Returns:?
tellurium.getAntimony(self)[source]¶

Antimony string of the current model state.

print(rr.getAntimony())
Returns:antimony string

jarnac Short-cuts¶

Routines to support the Jarnac compatibility layer

tellurium.getSm(self)[source]¶

Returns the full reordered stoichiometry matrix. Short-cut sm, e.g.

print(rr.sm())
Returns:full reordered stoichiometry matrix
tellurium.getRs(self)[source]¶

Returns the list of reaction Identifiers. Short-cut rs, e.g.

print(rr.rs())
Returns:reaction identifiers
tellurium.getFs(self)[source]¶

Returns list of floating species identifiers. Short-cut fs, e.g.

print(rr.fs())
Returns:floating species identifiers
tellurium.getBs(self)[source]¶

Returns list of boundary species identifiers. Short-cut bs, e.g.

print(rr.bs())
Returns:boundary species identifiers
tellurium.getPs(self)[source]¶

Returns list of global parameters in the model. Short-cut ps, e.g.

print(rr.ps())
Returns:global parameters
tellurium.getVs(self)[source]¶

Returns the list of compartment identifiers. Short-cut vs, e.g.

print(rr.vs())
Returns:compartment identifiers
tellurium.getDv(self)[source]¶

Returns the list of rates of change. Short-cut dv, e.g.

print(rr.dv())
Returns:rate of change
tellurium.getRv(self)[source]¶

Returns the list of reaction rates. Short-cut rv, e.g.

print(rr.rv())
Returns:reaction rates
tellurium.getSv(self)[source]¶

Returns the list of floating species concentrations. Short-cut sv, e.g.

print(rr.sv())
Returns:floating species concentrations
tellurium.getfJac(self)[source]¶

Returns the full Jacobian for the current model at the current state. Short-cut fjac, e.g.

print(rr.fjac())
Returns:Jacobian at current state

Test Models¶

Methods to acess the builtin test models.

RoadRunner has built into it a number of predefined models that can be use to easily try out roadrunner if so exmaple you don’t have a model at hand.

# To get the number of builtin models use listTestModels
print(roadrunner.listTestModels())
['feedback.xml', 'test_1.xml']

To load one of the test models use loadTestModel:

r = roadrunner.loadTestModel ('feedback.xml')
result = r.simulate (0, 10, 100)
r.plot (result)

If you need to obtain the SBML for the test model, use getTestModel

sbmlStr = roadrunner.getTestModel()
saveToFile('model.xml', sbmlStr)

To look at one of the test model in Antimony form:

antstr = te.sbmlToAntimony (roadrunner.getTestModel ('feedback.xml'))
print(antStr)
tellurium.loadTestModel(str)[source]¶

Loads particular test model into roadrunner.

rr = roadrunner.loadTestModel('feedback.xml')
Returns:RoadRunner instance with test model loaded
tellurium.getTestModel(str)[source]¶

SBML of given test model as a string.

# load test model as SBML
sbml = te.getTestModel('feedback.xml')
rr = te.loadSBMLModel(sbml)
# simulate
s = rr.simulate(0, 100, 200)
Returns:SBML string of test model
